sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving solutions
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the following reaction at 25°C, given that the enthalpies of formation for the reactants and products are:

HCl (aq) + NaOH (aq) → NaCl (aq) + H2O (l)

ΔH°f[HCl (aq)] = -92.31 kJ/mol

ΔH°f[NaOH (aq)] = -469.49 kJ/mol

ΔH°f[NaCl (aq)] = -407.29 kJ/mol

ΔH°f[H2O (l)] = -285.83 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔH° = Σ ΔH°f(products) - Σ ΔH°f(reactants)

In this case, the products are NaCl (aq) and H2O (l), and the reactants are HCl (aq) and NaOH (aq). Plugging in the given values for the enthalpies of formation, we get:

ΔH° = [(-407.29 kJ/mol) + (-285.83 kJ/mol)] - [(-92.31 kJ/mol) + (-469.49 kJ/mol)]

ΔH° = (-693.12 kJ/mol) - (-561.80 kJ/mol)

ΔH° = -131.32 kJ/mol

So, the standard enthalpy change for the reaction is -131.32 kJ/mol.
